choices.text: Evidence of psoriasis (current history, or family history)

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D)Presence of rheumatoid nodules.

Explanation:

According to the Classification of Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria for diagnosing psoriatic arthritis, a patient must accumulate 3 or more points from the given categories

questions.text: A 12y/o girl comes to the OPD with her parents complaining of multiple small, erythematous, scaly plaques on the trunk with a characteristic raindrop appearance 10 days after a streptococcal throat infection. An image of her lesions is given below. What is the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Penicillin

Explanation:

  • The presentation is classical of guttate psoriasis, often seen in children and adolescents.
     
  • It typically occurs 1–3 weeks after a streptococcal pharyngitis or upper respiratory tract infection.
     
  • The appropriate treatment includes:
     
    • Eradication of the triggering streptococcal infection using penicillin (or amoxicillin).
       
    • Topical therapies (like corticosteroids or emollients) may help skin symptoms but do not address the underlying cause.
       
    • Reassurance may be needed, but antibiotic therapy is essential in acute, post-streptococcal guttate psoriasis.
       

Clinical Features of Guttate Psoriasis:

Feature

Description

Age group

Common in children and young adults

Trigger

Post-streptococcal pharyngitis (esp. Streptococcus pyogenes)

Lesion morphology

Multiple, small (<1 cm), erythematous, scaly plaques ("drop-like")

Distribution

Trunk, proximal limbs

Course

May resolve spontaneously or evolve into chronic plaque psoriasis

 

 

Topical corticosteroids (Option A):
 

  • Incorrect as first-line monotherapy in acute guttate psoriasis post-infection.
     
  • Can be used adjunctively, but antibiotic therapy is essential to treat the underlying streptococcal cause.
     

Reassurance (Option B):
 

  • Incorrect as sole treatment. Although guttate psoriasis may be self-limited, reassurance alone is not adequate when a recent streptococcal infection is present.
     

Doxycycline (Option D):
 

  • Incorrect because it is not the first-line agent against streptococcal infection in children.
     
  • Penicillin or amoxicillin is preferred.

questions.text: An orthopaedic surgeon shows you an X-ray of  HLA B-27 positive female with seronegative arthritis and psoriatic skin lesions, and you observe the following deformity. What is the eponym given to this deformity?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B)Pencil-in-cup deformity

Explanation: 

 

Pencil-in-cup deformity

  • The "pencil-in-cup" deformity is a characteristic radiographic finding in patients with psoriatic arthritis.
  • Psoriatic arthritis occurs mainly in HLA B-27 positive patients and is seronegative.
  • It results from erosive changes at the joint margins, leading to bony proliferation and destruction, causing the proximal bone to taper into the distal bone.
  • It is often seen in the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints and is indicative of severe joint damage in psoriatic arthritis.
  • The tapered phalanx is also called the ‘mouse ear deformity.’

Ivory phalanx (Option A) occurs due to new bone formation in psoriatic arthritis; the phalanx may appear whiter due to sclerosis.

 

Boutonniere deformity (Option C) is commonly seen in rheumatoid arthritis, and involves flexion of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint with hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.

Fraying (Option D): Irregularity and thinning of the cortex of long bones, particularly at the metaphyses, resulting in a fuzzy or frayed appearance seen in vitamin C deficiency/ Scurvy.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presents to you with scaly, red follicular plaques over his body. He also has areas near his axilla that are spared from these lesions . What is the most likely histopathological pattern that is characteristic of his disease?

choices.text: Checkerboard pattern with alternate areas of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C)Checkerboard pattern with alternate areas of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis

Explanation:

  • Based on the clinical presentation of scaly, red follicular plaques with areas of sparing near the axilla also called islands of sparing, the diagnosis is Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP).
  • Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris is characterized by a histopathological finding known as the checkerboard pattern, which consists of alternate areas of hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum) and parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum).
  • Treatment includes topical agents, the same as that used in psoriasis including topical corticosteroids and emollients.

Hyperkeratosis

Parakeratosis

 


Acanthosis and spongiosis (Option A) are histopathological findings commonly seen in conditions such as psoriasis and eczema, but they are not characteristic of PRP.

Elongation of rete ridges (Option B) is a histological feature typically associated with psoriasis rather than PRP.

Lichenoid infiltrate with Civatte bodies (Option D) is a histopathological finding seen in lichen planus, which is a different dermatological disorder unrelated to PRP.

questions.text: A 24 year old girl with psoriatic skin lesions comes to the dermatology OPD with complaints of joint pain and worsening of her skin lesions. You want to use a single agent for managing both her skin disease and arthritis. Which of the following would you use?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A)Methotrexate

Explanation:

  • Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, thereby disrupting folate metabolism and interfering with DNA synthesis, leading to decreased proliferation of skin cells.
  • It also decreases the production of inflammatory cytokines eg. TNF-alpha and ILs, thereby reducing inflammation in the joints.

  • It is currently the most recommended single agent for managing both psoriatic arthritis and skin lesions.
  • Dosage: 7.5-25 mg/week via oral/subcutaneous route.
  • Common side effects of methotrexate include:
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
    • Hepatotoxicity necessitates regular monitoring of liver function tests.
    • Bone marrow suppression leads to anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia and requires monitoring through regular blood counts.
    • Long-term use: hepatotoxicity, pulmonary toxicity (including interstitial pneumonitis), and renal toxicity.

Oral corticosteroids (Option B):

  • They are used at times to control acute flares of psoriatic arthritis.
  • However, they are not preferred as a single agent for managing both skin disease and arthritis, considering their potential to cause instability of cutaneous psoriasis due to reactivation after stopping.

Cyclosporine (Option C):

  • It acts by inhibiting IL-2, a key cytokine involved in immune response modulation.
  • Often termed a "crisis drug," it is utilized to manage severe acute episodes of various immune-mediated disorders.
  • Due to its potential for adverse effects like hyperlipidemia and hypertension, cyclosporin is not used long-term for psoriasis with psoriatic arthritis.

Leflunomide (Option D) may be effective for arthritis, but it does not adequately address the skin disease aspect.

questions.text: Which of the following medications would not be used for treating a patient with moderate to severe psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D)Tocilizumab

Explanation:

Tocilizumab - It is a biological drug that targets the interleukin-6(IL-6) receptor, used primarily in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, giant cell arteritis, and juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

 


The characteristics of various topical treatments are shown in the table below

Aspect

Side Effects

Calcipotriene (also known as calcipotriol) and dithranol are examples of vitamin D analogs commonly used to treat psoriasis.

Adalimumab (Option A) is a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor. It works by blocking the action of TNF. It is used to treat various autoimmune conditions such as psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: Which of the following spectrums of UV Light is most commonly used in the treatment of psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B)UVB

Explanation:

  • UVB therapy, particularly narrow-band UVB, is the recommended first-line and most commonly used therapy for most patients with moderate to severe psoriasis.
  • Narrow-band UVB has a high effectiveness and tolerability compared to other UV spectra, such as broadband UVB and UVA (PUVA therapy).
  • The mechanism of NB-UVB is cutaneous immunomodulation by
    • Increasing vitamin D
    • Induction of apoptosis of T cells
    • Reduction of epidermal hyperproliferation

 

Wavelengths of various UV spectra are given in the image below.

 

UVA(Option A):

  • While UVA therapy (PUVA) has been used in the treatment of psoriasis, narrow-band UVB is preferred now.
  • PUVA therapy is associated with concerns regarding long-term side effects, including an increased risk of skin cancer.

UVC (Option C) exposure can be harmful to the skin and is not indicated for therapeutic purposes in psoriasis management.


UVD (Option D): "UVD light" is not a recognized term in the context of ultraviolet radiation. The standard terminology for ultraviolet radiation includes UVA, UVB, and UVC.

questions.text:
You are called by an ObGyn resident for the referral of care of a G2P1 woman with a known history of psoriasis, currently in her 2nd trimester. She is complaining of fever and malaise, and examination shows the following findings:



 

What could be a possible fetal complication in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C)Low birth weight

Explanation:

  • This patient with a known history of psoriasis and an image showing healing pustular lesions most likely has impetigo herpetifromis.
  • Impetigo herpetiformis is a rare and severe form of pustular psoriasis that typically occurs during pregnancy or postpartum.
  • It is characterized by widespread pustular eruptions with systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, and electrolyte imbalances.
  • A possible fetal complication in this patient with impetigo herpetiformis during the third trimester could be low birth weight, as the condition is associated with significant maternal and fetal risks, including intrauterine growth restriction and placental insufficiency.
  • Treatment includes
    • Admit the patient
    • IV Steroids/ Cyclosporine
    • Strict monitoring with appropriate IV fluids
    • Avoiding aggravating factors

 

No complications (Option A): Impetigo herpetiformis usually presents with fetal complications such as low birth weight and increased perinatal mortality.


Renal Agenesis (Option B):

  • It refers to the absence of one or both kidneys at birth, often leading to severe complications such as oligohydramnios, pulmonary hypoplasia, and an increased risk of urinary tract infections.
  • It is usually genetically inherited (Potter’s sequence) but could also be a complication of intake of ACE inhibitors or reno-toxic drugs during pregnancy.

Neonatal hypoglycemia (Option D):

  • It is characterized by low blood sugar levels in newborns, often due to inadequate glycogen stores or impaired glucose production.
  • It can lead to seizures, neurologic impairment, and long-term developmental issues if left untreated.
  • It is usually caused due to gestational diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A patient with a fever of 103°C and pain all over his body comes to your clinic. He recently went to a high-profile medical spa, where he was treated with oral medication for his chronic psoriasis. He was elated with the complete resolution during treatment but woke up with a fever, malaise, and pain three days ago. Skin examination is given in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Pustular psoriasis

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis of the image is pustular psoriasis (a type of unstable psoriasis) characterized by the presence of multiple sterile, non-infectious pus-filled blisters on erythematous skin, forming a characteristic 'Lakes of pus' appearance. 

 

  • This condition can occur due to the abrupt cessation of systemic corticosteroids, leading to rebound flare-ups of psoriasis.
  • Since it affects the whole body, it is also called Acute generalized pustular psoriasis or Von Zumbusch psoriasis.
  • Aggravating factors:
    • Withdrawal of steroids
    • Coal tar
    • Pregnancy
    • Stress

Classification of Unstable Psoriasis:

Erythrodermic psoriasis (Option B) is another variant of unstable psoriasis that presents with erythema and scales covering more than 90% of the body surface.

Psoriasis Vulgaris (Option C) also known as plaque psoriasis, is the most common form of psoriasis. It is characterized by raised, red patches of skin covered with silvery scales.

Rupioid psoriasis (Option D) is a severe form of psoriasis characterized by the development of large, thick, adherent, and waxy scales resembling limpet shells or oyster shells.

questions.text:
A 20 year old male patient comes to your dermatology OPD complaining of non-itchy lesions on the back of his elbows, shins, and knees. On examination, you find scaly lesions that exhibit the Auspitz sign, as shown in the image below. Which of the following processes is responsible for this patient's lesions?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Th1-mediated disorder

 

Explanation: 

  • The Auspitz sign, characterized by pinpoint bleeding in the areas where the lesion is scraped with a glass slide, is commonly associated with psoriasis, as depicted in the image above.

 

  • Psoriasis occurs via Th1-mediated immune responses, which are also involved in the pathogenesis of lichen planus.


The inflammatory modulators involved in a Th1 response are:

  • INF-γ (Th1 cells)
  • TNF-α (Th1 cells)
  • Th-17 (IL-17) (Th17 cells)
  • Th-22 (IL-22) (Th22 cells)

 

A detailed depiction of the pathogenesis is given in the image below.

 

Immune cells

Examples

Atopic dermatitis (eczema)

questions.text: A 24 year old male patient presents to you with joint pain in his fingers. He is currently a fashion student at NIFT and shares that other students bully him for having a few ‘sausage fingers.’ What type of arthritis would you most suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Asymmetrical oligoarthritis

Explanation:

In psoriatic arthritis (PsA), inflammation can affect the joints closest to the fingernails and toenails (DIP), resulting in swelling and inflammation. This inflammation can lead to the characteristic appearance of swollen and sausage-like fingers or toes. The image below is that of sausage toes.

According to Moll and Wright's classification of psoriatic arthritis, the percentage of patients with different types of psoriatic arthritis is as follows:

Clinical pattern of presentation

Percentage of patients

Asymmetrical oligoarthritis

50%

Symmetrical polyarthritis

40%

Distal interphalangeal arthritis

5%

Arthritis mutilans

5%

Spinal column or axial involvement

40%

The table above proves that the most common type of arthritis associated with psoriasis is asymmetric oligoarthritis (50%).

Distal interphalangeal arthritis (Option B) affects 5% of patients with psoriatic arthritis.


Spinal column or axial involvement (Option C) affects 40% of patients.

Arthritis mutilans (Option D) is a severe form of PsA characterized by destructive joint changes, but it is relatively rare with a prevalence of 5%.

questions.text: On examination of a specific finding in the nail, a dermatology professor confirms the presence of nail psoriasis. Which of these findings helped the professor establish this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Oil drop sign

Explanation:

  • The Oil drop sign refers to small, yellowish-orange discolorations seen beneath the nail plate, resembling drops of oil, and is highly specific for nail psoriasis.
  • It is the most specific sign of psoriasis with a specificity of ~98%
  • It occurs due to nail bed parakeratosis and psoriasiform hyperplasia
  • It occurs just before onycholysis

Important findings in nail psoriasis are (Mnemonic: POLISH)

  • Pits
  • Onycholysis
  • Leukonychia
  • Salmon patch
  • Subungual Hyperkeratosis

Pitting of the nails (Option A): While pitting is the most common finding in nail psoriasis, it is not as specific as the oil drop sign. Other diseases where pitting of nails is seen are : Alopecia Areata , Onychomycosis , Darier's disease , Hailey-Hailey disease etc. 

 

Onycholysis (Option C) or separation of the nail plate from the nail bed, can occur in various nail conditions including trauma and onychomycosis (fungal nail infection), not just nail psoriasis.

 

Subungual hyperkeratosis (Option D) refers to the thickening of the skin under the nail, which can also be seen in other nail disorders including eczema and hyperkeratosis, and is not specific to nail psoriasis.

questions.text: During your infectious disease rotation, you examine a 37 year old diabetic female with non-itchy lesions under both her breasts in the ward. The patient mentions that her lesions are non-itchy and exacerbate during the winter. They are salmon in colour, as shown in the image below. What is your next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Local application of corticosteroids

Explanation: 

  • These lesions are consistent with flexural or inverse psoriasis, characterized by non-itchy, salmon-coloured plaques in flexural areas like under the breasts.
  • As it is a variant of psoriasis, local corticosteroids help reduce inflammation and alleviate symptoms.
  • It's important to differentiate flexural psoriasis from candidal intertrigo, which is also common in similar areas but is itchy and lacks the characteristic bilaterally symmetrical scaly appearance.

Characteristics

Flexural Psoriasis

Candidal Intertrigo

 

Image

 

 

 

Colour

Salmon

Red, erythematous

Symmetry

Bilaterally symmetrical
  • Asymmetrical 
  • Satellite lesions are seen

Symptoms

Not pruritic

Pruritic

Exacerbation

Cold environment

Warm, humid environment

Treatment

Topical corticosteroids and emollients

Topical and oral antifungals


Reassurance (Option A) alone may not be sufficient as the patient's condition requires treatment to alleviate symptoms and prevent exacerbations.

Oral fluconazole (Option B) is not the appropriate choice because the lesions are not indicative of a fungal infection; they lack the typical features of candidiasis or tinea.

Oral corticosteroids (Option D) are not needed as the lesion is restricted to her breast region. Topical steroids can be applied to the specific site to resolve the lesion.

questions.text: An immigrant laborer comes to your Sunday volunteer clinic complaining of thickening of the skin on his scalp. The lesions are not itchy, cross the hairline, and are not associated with loss of hair as shown in the given image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Pityriasis amiantacea

 

Explanation: 

  • Pityriasis amiantacea is a scalp condition characterized by the formation of thick, asbestos-like scales that adhere to the hair shafts.

  • While the lesions are typically not itchy, they could cause hair loss if left untreated.
  • Can be secondary to an underlying inflammatory skin disorder such as:
    • Psoriasis
    • Lichen simplex
    • Scalp infections
  • Treatment
    • Topical corticosteroids
    • Keratolytic agents

Seborrheic dermatitis (Option B) is a scalp condition with red, itchy, greasy scales that affects areas rich in sebaceous glands, like the scalp, face, and upper trunk it can be caused by the fungi Malassezia furfur.

 

Pityriasis rosea (Option C) presents with oval-shaped, pink, or red patches on the trunk, arms, or legs. It doesn't involve the scalp, and the lesions don't cross the hairline. It is also caused by Malassezia furfur.

Tinea barbae (Option D) is a fungal infection of the beard area in men, characterized by erythematous plaques and pustules.

questions.text: During Dermatology grand rounds, a professor asks you to demonstrate the signs observed in patients with psoriasis. What is the order in which you will see these signs while scraping the lesion with the blunt end of a glass slide?

choices.text: Grattage sign, Berkeley’s Membrane, Auspitz Sign
Auspitz Sign, Berkeley’s Membrane, Grattage Sign
Berkeley’s Membrane, Grattage Sign, Auspitz Sign
Berkeley’s Membrane, Auspitz Sign, Grattage Sign

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Grattage sign, Berkeley’s Membrane, Auspitz Sign

Explanation: 

While examining a patient’s psoriatic lesions during scraping with a blunt object such as the blunt edge of a glass slide, the following signs are seen.


Grattage Sign/ Candle sign: Accentuation of scaling when the lesion is scraped with the blunt edge of a glass slide.

↓

Berkeley’s membrane: Formation of a thin membrane on further scraping.

↓

Auspitz sign: Formation of pin-point bleeding on scraping the Berkeley’s membrane.

Another sign, "Sign of the last Hauchen" or "Sign of the Last Scale," refers to the presence of small, raised, erythematous papules that become visible after the last scale is removed from a psoriatic plaque, i.e., before the formation of Berkeley’s membrane.

questions.text: While examining a patient with bilaterally symmetrical, silver-white scaly lesions during your Internal Medicine practical exam, you notice that each lesion is surrounded by an area of circumferential pallor as shown in the image below. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Woronoff’s ring

Explanation: 

Woronoff 's ring is a phenomenon where a ring-like area of lighter skin encircles fading psoriasis lesions.

  • As described above it is seen due to vasoconstriction (due to the absence of PGE2) and disruption of melanogenesis (autoimmunity).
  • It is characteristically seen in healing lesions.

 

Auspitz sign (Option A) is seen in psoriasis, referring to pinpoint bleeding when scales are removed by scraping.

Asboe-Hansen sign (Option B) can be demonstrated by the spreading of a blister by applying pressure at its edge, as seen in bullous pemphigoid

 

Nikolsky sign (Option D) indicates the detachment of the epidermis from the dermis with slight rubbing pressure, seen in pemphigus vulgaris , SSSS , Toxic epidermal necrolysis or Lyell's disease and other blistering disorders.

questions.text: While demonstrating the Koebner phenomenon as depicted in the image below to a group of medical students, a dermatology professor explains the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon as well. Which of the following is a disease that exhibits the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Warts

Explanation: 

  • The Koebner phenomenon, also known as the "isomorphic response," refers to the development of new skin lesions at sites of injury or trauma in individuals with certain dermatological conditions.
  • The classic phenomenon is commonly observed in conditions like psoriasis and lichen planus.
  • Pseudo-koebnerization is commonly seen in Verruca vulgaris (warts).
  • It is named after Heinrich Koebner, a dermatologist who first described this phenomenon with psoriasis.

Types of Koebnerisation
 

Category

Cause

Examples

Images

Category 1 (True koebnerization)

Development of lesions at sites of trauma.
  • Psoriasis
  • Lichen planus (Option A)
  • Vitiligo

Psoriasis

 

Category 2 (Pseudo koebnerization)

Non-immunological and occurs due to auto-inoculation and not trauma.
  • Verruca vulgaris (warts)
  • Molluscum

Warts

 

Category 3 (Occasional koebnerization)

The phenomenon is infrequent or occurs only in specific circumstances.
  • Darier disease
  • Erythema multiforme (Option D).

Erythema multiforme

 

Category 4 (Dubious association with trauma)

Limited evidence or conflicting reports regarding the role of trauma in lesion formation.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris (Option B)
  • Lupus erythematosus

Pemphigus vulgaris

questions.text: As a pathologist in a prestigious private clinic, a physician contacts you for urgent feedback on a skin biopsy from a prominent politician. Suspecting psoriasis, what histopathological findings in the stratum corneum would you communicate to the attending physician?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and microabscesses

Explanation: 

 

The various histopathological findings in the different skin layers seen in a patient with psoriasis are as follows.

 

Layer

Findings

Image

Stratum Corneum
  • Hyperkeratosis (increased thickening of stratum corneum)
  • Parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in stratum corneum)
  • Munro's microabscess (collection of neutrophils

Stratum Granulosum
  • Agranulocytosis/ Agranulosis (absent granular layer)

Malpighian layer (Stratum

Spinosum and Basale)
  • Acanthosis (increased thickness) of stratum spinosum
  • Kogoj's Spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils)

Rete ridges
  • They are elongated and club-shaped (Camel foot appearance).

 

Dermis
  • Suprapapillary thinning is seen as the first histopathological sign.
  • Dilated tortuous blood vessels.
  • Inflammation
  


Kogoj’s spongiform pustules (Option B) is a collection of neutrophils seen in the Malphigian layer.

Camel foot appearance (Option C) is seen in Rete ridges, which are elongated.

Suprapapillary thinning (Option D) is seen in the dermis.
